questions.text: In restrictive lung disease....
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

FEVI/FVC ratio is Normal/High.

questions.text: Following are the causes of Decreased DLCO EXCEPT :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Decreased DLCO. DLCO is a measure of Diffusion function (alveolar Integrity)

questions.text: PAO2-PaO2 gap normal with high PaCO2 is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypoventilation.
Approach to Hypoxemia :    Calculate Alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient)

	If A-a gradient is normal :    Low CO2 – Low FiO2 defect ( High Altitude)
	(Extra-pulmonary disease)    High CO2 – Hypoventilation syndromes

	If A-a gradient is high :	Assess response to oxygen therapy.	
	(Pulmonary disease)

	If responsive to oxygen : COPD, ILD, PTE (Disorder of V:Q mismatch)
	If unresponsive to O2    : Pulmonary edema, Pneumonia, ARDS (Alveolar defect)

questions.text: Type 1 respiratory failure best relates to which of the following :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Alveolar flooding

questions.text: A 25 year old man with a 6-year history of HIV-AIDS complicated recently by PCP was treated with high dose Co-Trimoxazole. On day 4 of treatment, the following laboratory data was obtained as follows : Na+ -135, K+-6.5, Cl-110, HCO3-15, pH-7.30, BUN-14, Creatinine-0.9, Osmolarity-268. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Non Anion gap metabolic acidosis
	Step wise approach :
1.pH is 7.30= acidosis
2.HCO3 is 15(low); pH and Hco3 change same direction= metabolic acidosis
3.AG= Na-(cl+hco3) = 135-(110+15)=10; normal anion gap.

questions.text: The term “ Excellent Bronchoreversibility” indicates improvement in FEV1 after Salbutamol inhalation by ----% of the pre-bronchodilator values.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

> 12% as per GINA guidelines.

questions.text: A  40 year old man presented with recurrent episodes of wheezing and hemoptysis. CXR shows perihilar bronchiectasis. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ABPA
Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder that occurs in response to allergic sensitization to antigens from Aspergillus species fungi. The predominant clinical presentation of ABPA is an asthmatic phenotype，often accompanied by cough with production of brownish plugs of mucus. ABPA has also been well described as a complication of cystic fibrosis. ABPA is a distinct diagnosis from simple asthma， characterized by prominent peripheral eosinophilia and elevated circulating levels of IgE (>417 IU/mL). Establishing a diagnosis of ABPA also requires establishing sensitivity to Aspergillus antigens by skin test reactivity, positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus and/or direct measurement of circulating specific IgG and IgE to Aspergillus. Central bronchiectasis is described as a classic finding on chest imaging in ABPA but is not necessary for making a diagnosis. Other possible findings on chest imaging include patchy infiltrates and evidence of mucus impaction. Systemic glucocorticoids may be used in the treatment of ABPA that is persistently symptomatic despite the use of inhaled therapies for asthma. Monoclonal antibody against IgE (Omalizumab) can be used in treating severe ABPA, particularly in individuals with ABPA as a complication of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: 63 years gentleman, chronic smoker had a 3 year history of cough with intermittent episodes of fever and breathlessness. CXR revealed prominent Broncho-vesicular markings with Cardiomegaly. Recently he reports weight loss of 6kg in last 2 months. On examination, there is Grade 3 clubbing. What is the most probable diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchogenic Carcinoma.  COLD does not cause clubbing. In a patient with COLD, the presence of clubbing indicates super-added infection / Bronchogenic carcinoma.

questions.text: You see a 68 year old gentleman with a 40 pack year history in your clinic. He is experiencing breathlessness on exertion and a productive cough of white sputum over the last 4 months. You assess his spirometry results which reveal an FEV1/FVC of 51% with minimal bronchoreversibility after a 2 week trial of oral steroids. Cardiological investigations are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: The severity of COLD is assessed using post bronchodilator spirometry analysis. From the list below, select the values that you would expect to see in a patient with moderate COLD :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

GOLD criteria : GOLD 1 FEV1 >= 80% of predicted – Mild disease GOLD 2 FEV1 = 50-79% of predicted – Moderate disease GOLD 3 FEV1 = 30-49% of predicted – Severe disease GOLD 4 FEV1 < 30% of predicted – Most severe disease

questions.text: The new drug recommended for the management of severe COLD is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Roflumilast is an oral PDE4 inhibitor which is approved for severe COLD.

questions.text: A 67-year old woman is admitted to the casualty with pyrexia (38.1) and a cough productive of green sputum. The observations show a Pulse rate of 101/min, BP 80/60 and Respiratory rate of 32/min. She is alert and oriented in time and space. Investigations reveal TLC of 21000, Urea of 8.5 and x-ray reveals consolidation in the right lung. She is treated for CAP. Which of the following is the correct calculated CURB 65 score ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Total score is 4.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman with unexpected weight loss, loss of appetite and shortness of breath comes to your clinic. On examination, there is reduced air entry and dullness on percussion in the right lung. A diagnostic pleural tap was performed and aspirate sent for analysis. The result reveals a Serum to Pleural fluid albumin gradient of 2.1. from the given list, select the most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bronchogenic carcinoma – Pleural fluid - exudative

questions.text: Carrico’s index in ARDS is calculated as :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Carrico’s index is PaO2/FiO2. This is the most important parameter for both diagnosis and prognosis of ARDS.

questions.text: Match the Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis syndromes with the corresponding antigen :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypersentivity Pneumonitis/ Extrinsic allergic alveolitis

questions.text: A 54 years old Male, Mountaineer presents with history of progressive breathlessness since last 3 months. He had a trip to Mansarovar 6 months back which was uneventful. HRCT findings are as in the picture. Lung Biopsy shows heterogenous patchy fibrosis with several fibroblastic foci. The most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

UIP – Bilateral Honey-comb appearance due to traction bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Nintedanib used in the palliative treatment of Idiopathic Pulmonary  Fibrosis is tyrosine kinase against
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

VEGF

questions.text: Sleep apnea is defined as a temporary pause in breathing during sleep at least....
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Apnea is cessation of breathing > 10 secods in adults.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT an indication for urgent dialysis in acute renal failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Indications of Dialysis in AKI :
	1. Urea > 100
	2. Creatinine > 7
	3. Refractory Pulmonary edema
	4. Refractory Hyper K+ > 6.5
	5. Refractory Metabolic acidosis pH < 7.20
	6. Serious Uremic complications

questions.text: A 27 year old man with history of recurrent hematuria during childhood, presents with chronic kidney disease. His maternal uncle died of ESRD 2 years ago. On eye examination, he has a posterior subcapsular cataract. The diagnosis IS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Alports syndrome – X-linked defect of Typer 4 collagen. Manifesting in 2-3rd decade of life with renal failure, Sensori-neural deafness and Lenticonus/subcapsular cataract.

questions.text: In a patient of fairly advanced diabetic nephropathy, the most common finding on electron microscopy IS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In DM nephropathy – EM finidings :
	1. Early stages : Thickening of GBM
	2. Late stages  :  Nodular Glomerulosclerosis

questions.text: The most common Bone disease in CKI
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: The most common form of Anaemia in CKI
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Peritoneal Dialysis has following complications except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Weight gain occurs due to Hyperglycemia.

Complications of Peritoneal Dialysis 
1.	Peritonitis (usually Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, or coliforms) 
2.	Catheter blockage
3.	Weight gain and poor diabetic control (dialysate fluid had high sugar content)
4.	Pleural effusion.

questions.text: Goodpasture’s antigen is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Alpha 3 subunit of type 4 collagen.

Good Pastures syndrome
•	This is characterized by lung hemorrhage, GN, and circulating antibody to basement membrane, usually in young men. Hemoptysis may precede nephritis. 
•	Rapidly progressive renal failure is typical 
•	Circulating anti – glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibody and linear immune – fluorescence on renal biopsy establishes the diagnosis 
Plasma exchange may produce remission.

questions.text: A 40 year old female comes with Loin pain. Urine examination shows 120 rbc/hpf. Urine microscopy revealed dysmorphic RBC’s in urine. The site of origin is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Spot urinary Albumin to creatinine ration

questions.text: The most preferred test for detection of Microalbuminuria
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spot urinary ACR

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:
ph – 7.36
PaCO2 – 70 mm
HCO3 – 36 mEq
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chronic Respiratory Acidosis

The ABG shows Primary Respiratory acidosis. To differentiate we need to look at the relation to change in pH with change in PaCO2 in Acute vs Chronic disease.
In Acute Respiratory acidosis, there is no time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.4 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2.
In Chronic Respiratory acidosis, there is time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.1 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2.

choices.text: Metabolic Acidosis with Compensatory respiratory Alkalosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Additional Respiratory Acidosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Additional Respiratory Alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:
ph – 7.20
PaO2 – 69mm
PaCO2 – 30 mm
HCO3 – 15 mEq
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Metabolic Acidosis with Compensatory respiratory Alkalosis

Compensation in case of Metabolic acidosis i.e. expected change in CO2 due to acidosis is calculated using Winter’s formula: (1.5*Pts HCO3 value) + 8 +/- 2.
In the given question, the ph is 7.20 indicating acidosis. (Hence NOT Option D)
HCO3 is less than normal indicating Primary Metabolic acidosis. 
According to Winter’s formula: Expected PaCO2 in this patient should be 30+/-2 mm. 
Since the PaCO2 in the report is as expected, there is no additional respiratory defect and the change in PaCO2 (i.e. Respirator Alkalosis) is compensatory to the primary defect.

questions.text: 20-year-old asthmatic male on bronchodilator therapy since childhood walks into the casualty with acute onset shortness of breath. He is able to lie down on the bed for examination. P- 102/min, RR- 26/min, SpO2 – 97% on room air with a drop of Systolic blood pressure by 6 mm on inspiration. Auscultation reveals expiratory wheeze. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Formoterol inhalation + ICS

The case describes an acute attack of asthma, however there is no orthopnea, cyanosis, pulsus paradoxus or silent chest suggesting a mild/moderate attack which WAS best treated in the hospital with salbutamol nebulization.
But SABA alone relieves the symptoms but doesnot prevent relapses. Hence GINA update recommends LABA + ICS. Salmeterol is only for prophylaxis and NOT for acute attack

questions.text: Atypical pneumonia can be caused by all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, Staph and Streptococci are included under organisms causing classical pneumonia.

questions.text: The only ILD exclusively found in smokers is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

DIP
Desqaumative Interstital Pneumonia is exclusively found in smokers.
Smoking protects against ILD in Hypersensitivity pneumonitis and Sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Tezepelumab is approved for the prophylaxis of bronchial asthma. Its MOA is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TSLP inhibitor

Tezepelumab is first in class human monoclonal antibody immunoglobulin G2-lambda that inhibits TSLP (Thymic stromal lymphopoietin)

questions.text: A young male presents with complaints of passing blood in the urine. Urine microscopy revealed following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glomerulonephritis
The urine microscopy revealed RBC cast which is rare but diagnostic of Glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: An elderly lady developed urinary tract infection. She was started on a course of Nitrofurantoin. After 5 days she had resolution of symptoms. However, laboratory shows mild elevation of serum Creatinine with eosinophilic cast in the urine. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stop the Nitrofurantoin
The patient has resolution of urinary infection with Nitrofurantoin. However, the elevated Creatinine with eosinophiluria indicates drug induced Interstitial nephritis. The treatment is to stop the drug.

questions.text: The most sensitive parameter to differentiate Intrinsic AKI from Pre-renal AKI is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

FeNa

FeNa – Fractional excretion of sodium is the most sensitive parameter to differentiate Renal and Pre-renal AKI

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with Ischemic cardiomyopathy in Chronic HF presents complaining of nausea and vomiting. Examination reveals Grade 2 pedal edema and elevated JVP. Laboratory values include serum Na of 125 mmol/L, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 25 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, urine Na of 40 with FeNa of 5%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute Tubular necrosis (ATN)
 
The case of chronic heart failure indicates chronic hypoperfusion leading to acute tubular necrosis. Fractional excretion of sodium [FENa(%)] is used in determining the cause of renal failure. FENa(%) = (urine sodium/serum sodium)/(urine creatinine/serum creatinine) × 100.

questions.text: A 45 years old Male presented with cough with haemoptysis. On examination there is a purpuric skin rash. There is associated hearing impairment with foreign body sensation in the eyes. On investigation Urine revealed presence of dysmorphic RBC and RBC cast. Serum Creatinine is 3.2.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wegener’s granulomatosis

questions.text: The most common cause of FSGS is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

DM nephropathy
All the causes lead to FSGS. DM is most common cause.

choices.text: Alpha-3 subunit of Type 4 collagen is most commonly affected
Anterior Lenticonus is a specific feature of the disease

questions.text: Identify the false statements regarding Alport’s syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alpha-3 subunit of type 4 collagen is most commonly affected
Alport’s syndrome is a X-linked defect most commonly affecting Alpha 5>4 subunit of Type 4 collagen. GBM affection causes recurrent hematuria due to GN. Cochlear basement membrane involvement causes deafness. Anterior Lenticonus is rare but specific feature of the disease. Skin involvement is asymptomatic but Skin biopsy is a useful screening test as it is easy to access. Renal transplant offers potential cure and associated with good prognosis.

questions.text: Causes of CKD with enlarged kidneys are all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alport’s syndrome

Causes of Enlarged kidneys in CKD include:
1. DM nephropathy
2.HIVAN
3. Renal Amyloidosis (myeloma kidney)
4. APKD

questions.text: The most dreaded manifestation of Systemic sclerosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pulmonary hypertension leading to Heart failure has replaced RPGN as the most common cause of mortality in SSc patients.

questions.text: Match the diseases with corresponding findings
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2

choices.text: Primary site of joint involvement is Enthesis.

questions.text: Features of axial spondyloarthritis include all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Spondyloarthropathies are a group of disorders having following common features:
•	Strong Family history of arthropathy (HLA-B27positive)
•	Enthesitis is primary site of joint involvement
•	Axial involvement is not uncommon
•	RA Factor is negative
•	Extra-articular features predominate
•	Excellent response to NSAIDS

questions.text: c-ANCA positivity indicates antibody formed against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

c-ANCA positivity indicates antibody formed against Proteinase 3 (PR3).

questions.text: All of the following are associated with HLA-B27 except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RA

questions.text: Which is the target uric acid level for the treatment of gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

< 7 mg/dl

choices.text: Polyarticular arthritis does not involve the small joints of the hands
Polyarticular psoriatic arthritis spares the ankle joints
Polyarticular psoriatic arthritis is the most severe subtype of psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: Which statement about polyarticular psoriatic arthritis is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Polyarticular arthritis is often symmetrical and mimics RA

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation in RA is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

keratoconjunctivitis sicca

questions.text: The most potent DMARD in RA is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Methotrexate
